div.u: [In Yiddish] What is your name, sir?
[In English] Spool 125, taken in Hénonville, near Paris in a Kibbutz which is maintained by the Agudah. Yes.
[Word not clear.]

Yes. It is a cooperative arrangement between the World ORT which handles the teaching of various trades and agriculture and the Agudah which maintains the place and seems to own this wonderful chateau . . . chateau of old, rich Frenchman, abandoned rather in a bad state of disrepair, because the ceiling are high. The . . . to paint it and to paper it would probably cost as much as the triple number of apartments in America where the same number of people could live. And so we have Mr. Solomon Horowitz who is the Rabbi in the place.
[In Yiddish] And so, Rabbi . . . Rabbi, would you tell me again what is your name and how old are you?
I am, in the year nineteen . . .
What is your name?
Solomon Horowitz.
Yes?
Born in nineteen nine.
Nineteen . . . when?
Nineteen nine.
Nineteen nine?
Nine.
So you are quite young. You are thirty-seven years old.
Yes, yes, thirty-seven years.

[In English] All right. The Rabbi looks very well. He has a medium length beard and has a very good complexion . . . here in the country. [In Yiddish] And so go on. Would you tell me, Rabbi, what had happened to you? Where were you when the war started?

When the war started I was the Rabbi in Potok-Zloty. That is in the region of Galicia, near Tarnopol, Tarnopol Woje[wodstwo] region of Tarnopol. There I have . . . there were immediately deported from my little town . . .
And so let us not go so fast. The war started. Who entered? What kind of soldiers entered?
The Germans, the Germans, the Germans.
The Germans entered.
The Germans entered.
Nu, and what did they . . .
Immediately deported the entire little town . . .
But . . .
'Jews, out!'
And so you would describe . . .
Yes.
. . . the procedure.
Yes.
How were people deported? Did they say . . . well, how was it? What did they say to the Jews? To whom of the Jews did they speak? Did you have an administration? How did the entire thing come about?
They immediately organized a kind of a Jewish council.
Yes?
It was called . . . There they took in a few people . . .
Yes.
And the people . . . They demanded from these people that they should put at their disposal a registration of each Jew, of all the possessions on hand.
Hm.
It was done that way. They registered.
How many Jews were there in your town, in your . . .
Fourteen . . . fourteen hundred persons.
All together fourteen hundred persons?
Fourteen hundred persons. Yes.
Hm. And how many Christians were there?
Christians, there were three times as many.
You figure that the Jews were approximately . . .
A quarter, a quarter, a quarter.
A quarter. Yes, nu?
Then they ordered the Jewish councils, and they registered all the Jews. And it was ordered that in fourteen days there should not be found a Jew in that little town.
Oh! They wanted to make this little town Jew-clean?
Jew-clean.
Yes.
Where do the Jews have to go? To the county seat, to a larger town which is eighteen kilometers away. The name of it is Buczacz.
Yes.
Buczacz was the county seat of Potok-Zloty, of my town [?]. In Buczacz were concentrated from the entire region around sixteen thousand Jews, gathered together . . .
Hm.
. . . in that town. In that town proper a ghetto was created. It was ordered that in such and such a street all the Jews have to be.
Oh. A ghetto was made in that town.
In that town. In that street.
How many streets? One single street?
One or two.
Two. That means sixteen thousand . . .
Sixteen thousand. It was indeed terrible. Indeed the Polish [?] Jews were lying in the street.
Yes?
It was terrible.
What time of the year was it, Rabbi?
In the year '40.
No, I mean which, winter, summer? When was it?
In the middle of the winter, in blizzards they ordered to . . . When we went the snow was terrible. Jews froze on the carts [word not clear] from cold. In the severest frosts.
Nu?
And in Buczacz again was created a Jewish council.
Hm.

Again a Jewish council. And the Jewish council was ordered to gather together all the gold and silver. Whoever has even a deka of gold, even a ring, no matter what, should be brought immediately. We went around. I, too, was one who went to collect from all the Jews all the gold in possession. We thought with that gold we might save ourselves for a certain time and will be allowed to live.
So did you give the gold or . . .

Everything. There didn't remain an iota [?]. I myself went along in order that it should be . . . should be handled honestly. I as Rabbi, because those members of the Jewish council were scum . . . Some were scoundrels [?], not such clean, decent people. Because usually he [the German], when he had to take people and go and rob . . . rob the . . . his [own] brothers, he took the scum, low elements. In spite of that I went along so that the gold should be delivered. We thought that with this gold we will save ourselves a little, for a certain time.
Nu, I will tell you . . .
Yes.
There is another point of view. Maybe they were told, the people that went along into the Jewish council . . .
Yes?
. . . that if . . . if one should give in to the Germans a little they will not be that bad.
That is what we did. That is . . . that is how we figured. That is how we figured.
Were you in the Jewish council?
No. I was not in the Jewish council. I was outside the Jewish council, but the Jewish council usually summoned me as . . . as an individual, as a religious dignitary.
Yes, yes.
Religious dignitary. I was of the opinion that we should give them the gold and silver. I was of such opinion because . . . so that we should save ourselves.
Yes.
[Words not clear.] As soon as they collected the gold and silver -- it took abut fourteen days -- there came again the Gestapo from Czortkow, from [by order of] the higher authorities . . .
Hm.
. . . and demanded a contingent of people.
Yes?
It was ordered [?] that as long as there is no more gold and silver, as we have no more possessions, we should hand over for instance, five hundred people to . . . to be killed.
To be killed?
To be killed. [Word not clear.] At first he said to be evacuated.
Not for labor? Not to be arrested [?]?
No. To be killed.
It was said so?
Said openly!
Said openly?
Twelve hundred sould have to be handed over to be killed. It was ordered [?] that a contingent of people . . .
What did you say was the name of that little town?
Buczacz.
Buczacz?
Buczacz.
It wasn't said to go for labor? It wasn't . . .
Nothing! The first transports it was said [are] for deportation.
Oh!
For deportation. They were taken to Belzyce. There was a 'Place of Repose' [burial ground] of millions of people. Belzyce.
Yes.
There was a factory . . .
Yes.
. . . where people were destroyed electrically. These were the first three transports.
Wait a moment. What kind of factory?
Bel- . . . in Belzyce. You don't know? It was a milli . . . milli . . .
You mean Bels . . . Bergen-Belsen.
No. Belzyce.
Belzyce.
In the region of Lemberg.
Yes.
There was a factory into which he brought millions of people.
Hm.

And it was later that he made fats out of them. It has been confirmed. It was a gigantic . . . like Treblinka. You don't know about Bel- . . . Belzyce? It is an atrocious thing. There were [people] brought from Poland and from Switzerland [?]. Millions of Jews were burned.
Belzyce is not the same as Treblinka? Belzyce is . . .
It is not. Treblinka is different, a different hell, and this is a different hell.
Nu, tell me, who has seen that? Who knows it? You say it was . . .
It is known. It is known exactly, because people jumped off the trains . . .
Nu?

. . . during the journey to Belzyce. They were already undressed nude a few kilometers before Belzyce. And it is known exactly what was done there with the people. One knows exactly. But from Buczacz there were only three transports to Belzyce.
Nu?
. . . because later on he begrudged the trains. He saw that people are jumping off.
Yes?
So he didn't come any more with transports. But he arrived. And he took out a few hundred Jewish workers. They should dig graves.
Hm.
To be dug eight days before . . .
Yes?

A grave was dug in Buczacz . . . there is . . . which is six kilometers . . . [Footnote: He is either utterly confused about the actual measurements, or a ditch was dug for another purpose, possibly for drainage, or just punitive work accompanied by intentional terror rumors. See note on page 56 2(2012).]
Hm.
. . . in . . . in length.
Hm.

Such a grave was dug. And later on Jews were led out. He asked to be given Jews, a . . . a contingent of five hundred or a thousand people for slaughter. Naturally the Jewish council did not want to. They said, 'Who should be handed over and who should remain?' [You decide.]
Hm.
So the people said [to the Germans], 'Go and take yourself.' So he went around himself, from house to house.
The German?
The German. The Germans went around with militia.
Yes?
And they took . . . from house to house people were taken out to be killed. Then we began digging bunkers underneath the floors . . .
Yes

. . . in every house to hide ourselves. They entered a house. They went around like this and knocked and dug until they found. They took out from bunkers, I don't know, Jews by the fifties or hundreds. Instead of the thousand burned offerings they had originally asked for, they gathered three thousand.
Hm.
They were led out, and Jews themselves had to bury them. All were shot. They left only twenty, thirty Jews, and said these twenty, thirty Jews should bury the dead.
Did you see that yourself?

Yes! Later on these twenty, thirty were alas, shot. What does 'saw' mean? I put up a gravestone on that large and holy place, on that large mass . . . mass grave. I have just put up a gravestone. There lie all my relatives, all my brothers and sister everybody. Six . . . six . . . six thousand Jews lie there in one grave. What does 'saw' mean? It is a fact! Some question! Thus was done very time. It was done. These were called 'actions' It was called . . .
Yes?
. . . an action takes place.
Hm.
Every three, four weeks an 'action' was made until in Buczacz only two thousand Jews remained, the last two thousand Jews.
And where were you during all this time?
In all I went through thirteen 'actions' and remained alive. Thirteen 'actions' I have gone through under the ground in my . . . my house.
Oh. Under the ground in your house! You were hiding?
Not hiding! Everybody was hiding. As soon as . . .
Oh!
. . . the Germans raided as an 'action' every . . . everybody would hide in any kind of hiding place he had.
Yes?
But people were found. Whoever succeeded, succeeded. Those who weren't discovered weren't discovered. I had gone through thirteen 'actions' in Buczacz. And I lost the family in the eleventh 'action.'
Where was . . . where had the family been?
The family was together with me.
Nu?
We were in a pit. Eighty person . . . were we . . .
Such large did you make?
Eighty persons. We made a gigantic underground cellar. And I let in . . . everybody let in only twenty, thirty.
Under whose house was it? Your house?
Under . . . under . . . .Yes.
Your house.
No, not my own. There where I was living.
Oh.
The Jewish council gave me to live in.
Hm.

And there, under the ground, we dug out a cel- . . . cellar, dug out with three walls [partitions?] extremely well camouflaged. And there I took in eighty people, because I saw everybody only kept in a bunker twenty, thirty, but I saw there were people shelterless, who didn't have any bunker.
Hm.
So I told them they should come to me and hide. This perhaps brought about the . . . the tragedy.
Yes?
Because of that it was discovered. There was . . . I can describe to you the night of the catastrophe. During eleven . . . eleven 'actions' my bunker was . . . was saved, was not discovered.
Yes?

During the eleventh 'action' we had already been 'bunkered.' We heard that the Gestapo had arrived, out for an 'action.' We had 'bunkered' ourselves around twelve o'clock at night. Around two o'clock at night I heard voices from the outside in these words, that is, in substance, 'We are six persons, a Hungarian family.' [He quotes in a slow, solemn voice./
Hm.
'We are standing outside.'
Hm.
'The murderers are not yet on this street. Have compassion, Jews, and let us in . . . '
Hm.

' . . . because we are standing unprotected, in danger of being killed. The murderers are not yet in this street. Maybe we can still be saved!' I heard that lying in the bunker. I tore open the cover of the bunker. I said to myself, 'I don't want to save myself, to save myself and have on my conscience six . . . six burned offerings, Hungarian Jews.' I unscrewed [the cover of] the bunker and ran out to the gate of the house and took in that family. And then, at the moment when I took them in, a few of the Gestapo already on the street sensed that something is going on in this house.
That family really was a real Jewish family?
Yes. I took them in.
It was not a made up thing?
No. I took them in, that family . . .
Hm.
. . . to us, and they were indeed with us.
Hm.
And two hours later they overran the house . . .
Yes?
. . . because they had sensed something, as if near this house there is some sort of scent.
Yes.
They stopped at the house and were shooting from all sides, and eventually the bunker was discovered.
Hm.

Then my whole family was also gathered together with the eighty persons. Everybody was led out and shot, and I with my only son that I possess, fifteen years old, in the last moment between the baggage -- there was a lot of baggage among eighty persons, featherbeds and sacks . . .
Yes?
So I lay down among these sacks and featherbeds on the ground.
Yes?
Thus, because of the great noise and the tumult and the screams . . .
Hm.
. . . these two people, my child and I, they left behind. I was lying among the baggage. I was trod on with the feet.
Hm.
And I wasn't noticed.
Hm.
I gave my whole family the advice. They scattered in small groups.
Yes?
Unfortunately, they were seen. They were all picked up and led away.
Hm.
I had eleven persons in my family.
Hm.
And I with my only boy remained in the cellar.
How old was your boy?
He is here. He is here. Fifteen years.
Hm. And the . . . the others from your family were your wife . . .
A wife with five sisters . . .
Hm.
. . . with a child, . . .
Hm.
. . . with a father, may his memory be blessed . . .
Oh! You had only one child?
I had this child and the other child, two children.
Yes.
This child remained [with] me, the older one . . .
Yes?
. . . and a boy of nine years . . .
Yes.
. . . who sho- . . . sho- . . . showed abilities of becoming one of the world's great . . . he was . . .
A what?
He showed me abilities of becoming one of the world's great . . . he was . . .
A what?
He showed abilities of becoming one of the world's great . . .
In what . . . eh . . .
In what field? In the field of memory [word not clear]. He had a terrific memory, and simply in . . . in intelligence. By himself he had already memorized a terrific amount of biblical knowledge.
Hm.
He remembered half of the Book of Psalms by heart.
Hm.

When he went to the . . . the slaughter, to be slaughtered, he was saying the Psalms from memory. And he said two thousand Jews were being led. He said, 'I am still going to pray to God. Maybe in the last moment we will be saved.' An unusual, and extraordinarily gifted child of nine years. They have murd- . . . [interrupted]
How did you find out about that? Who told you that?
One was saved. From that transport one had escaped during . . . because when the transports were being taken some would run away. They would shoot after [them].
Hm.
One out of thousands might be saved, because there were so many militia men. They guarded strongly.
Hm.

But one was saved, and he told me how . . . he pictured to me enough how they were killed. My . . . my entire family I lost then. After that, when I saw that there remained in Buczacz the last two thousand Jews -- I already had lost my family -- I talked it over. I said, 'It is getting to be Jew-clean. Let us escape to the forests. In town there is no more place for us. Let us run to the forests!'
Hm.
I gathered three hundred and fifty Jews and brought them out into the forests. There . . .
Tell me, how . . . what does it mean, you 'gathered them'? You told them they should come, or what?
I told them that they should come in groups to such and such woods.
Hm.
In such and such direction.
Yes?
And there I will be found, and another group of Jews. And there we will plan how we will support ourselves and which peasant we could trust to bring food.
Hm.
There we will plan how to hide under ground.
Hm.
And we shall talk it over. Maybe, maybe there in the woods, we will live through Hitlerism. [Pause.]
And so afterwards?
[Pause.] Afterwards [pauses again] we were . . . A month later while in the woods, we were reported to the Gestapo, that there are Jews in the woods.
Hm. Can you describe what people did all day in the forest? Where did one sleep? Where did one . . . Describe the life in the forest . . . in the forest.

The life in the forest was a constant terror. One was afraid during every second that there may come a group of Gentiles and kill us all. People looked only for thicker trees to hide. All day long people thought only about one thing, to save one's life. Days passed when people forgot even about the need to eat. There passed entire days in which one neither ate nor slept. And when one became tired, one lay down on the grass. Once it rained constantly for three days. And it became so muddy that afterwards, when we got up, people got lost. We couldn't find one another. Thus we were submerged, covered with mud. That is how we slept in a forest. And at the beginning the food consisted of mushrooms from the trees, around the trees, on the ground. There are such dark mushrooms.
What is that? [Did not understand the Polish word grzyby.]
Dark mushroom. It is such a . . . [with distaste] it is a disgusting food.
The bark, the . . . the bark? Kora? What . . .
Yes. Like bark. Black bark.
Yes, yes.
This we ate. One peeled it and boiled it in water.
Hm.
And one ate it, and the water in which it was boiled we drank.
[Clarifying the word] Cooked?
Cooked. Cooked. One took water, [word not clear] water. One boiled it thoroughly, and this one ate.
Nu, were there only men, or were there . . .

Oh, women also. Women and children. Among the three hundred and fifty there were engineers and doctors and rabbis, all sorts of people. An assemblage of various sorts of people. And the engineers began planning how to make underground bunkers.
Hm.
And we made in the area of five kilometers . . . there were made forty bunkers. An area of forty bunkers. In each bunker there were a few people, in fives, in sixes, in tens.
Hm.

And it was thus. In the daytime we lay the whole under . . . underground. And we were afr- . . . afraid that should a peasant get lost there, a Gentile with a cow, it will soon be known that there are Jews in the forest. So we lay all day long underground. In the evening, at night, we permitted ourselves to go out . . .
Hm.

outside to take a bit of fresh air, because at night we weren't afraid of a raid. It was a forest dense with trees. So at night we used to come together from all the bunkers to one place, to one assembly point . . .
Hm.

. . . around me. And we used to make campfire, a fire around us. We baked potatoes and sat and talked about what will become of us. While we were in the forest, Russian partisans arrived. That was very interesting. Parachutes descended. Thirty partisans . . .
Parachutes?
Parachutes.
Into the forest? Or was it . . .
No. They descended in an open place. They ran. They were . . . they knew that the Germans are there. They were Russians.
Hm.
So they ran into the forest hide.
Yes.
They had descended on an open place, on . . . on a landing place.
Yes.
There is where they had descended. And they came to us, into the forest, thirty persons, Russians. And they were hiding with us for six weeks.
Hm.

And so we had partisans. They were armed. Our spirit rose. Now we already have a little . . . a bit of arms. If an attack comes we had something with which to defend ourselves. These partisans . . . during their stay we lived well because they would raid. At night they would go into the villages and attack the peasants and burn the crops. They would spread damage. They would, in the meantime, bring provisions from the peasants.
What would they burn? What did they use to burn?
To burn grains.
What is it? [The word was not understood.]
They used to burn grain, rye, wheat.
Yes.
Wheat, the field.
Yes.
They wanted to do damage.
Oh! That was sabotage.
Yes. Sabotage. They descended in the . . . the time of the harvest.
Hm.
They descended when the crops were harvested.
Yes.
To spread sabotage, to cause great damages [?].
Yes.
At that time they burned, and in the meantime from . . . from the peasants they took food and brought it to the woods.
Yes.
Then on one occasion they brought a radio to the forest. They had taken away from a Ukrainian a rad- . . .
A radio?
A radio.
For receiving or sending?
No. They brought a radio to us to the forest.
An ordinary radio.
Yes. An ordinary radio, and we . . . that radio . . . an engineer took that radio and 'bunkered' it. It was tied with wires to a tree.
Yes.

And it was powered with fifteen batteries. We had it every night. Fifteen batteries were bought. People were sent. They risked their lives. They were disguised as Gentiles into the towns to buy batteries, so that we should every night, every evening get some news of what is going on in the world.
Hm. Was it possible to buy the small . . . what were the . . . what kind of batteries were they?
Batteries. Such simple . . . simple batteries. Simple, and with that the engineer powered the radio.
Hm.
With the batteries every night we listened to the news.
Hm.

We got together. It was near me. Gathered together all the three hundred and fifty Jews, sitting up at night. We turned on the radio. The radio began to inform us when the first advance against Kharkov, when they made the Germans pull back from Kharkov.
Oh. When they chased away the Germans?
Chased away, yes.
Yes?
We heard over the radio about how Kharkov was taken . . . .
Hm.
. . . all the points along the Dnieper.
Hm.
We heard over the radio about all the occupations [of cities]. They were advancing with the swiftness, right up to the suburb of Kiev. The radio had led us . . .
Hm.
We heard that the Soviets were already patrolling the suburbs of Kiev.
Hm.
And then, at that time, it already brought us a bit . . . a bit of hope that they will approach closer. I used to sit all day long, writing with pencil on . . . on the plan, with a map . . .
Yes?
. . . to try and figure out how many kilometers they cover in a day, how long it has to take till they come to us.
And how far were you from Kiev?
From Kiev? We were still far from Kiev, over a thousand kilometers.
Oh! Oh!

[Chuckles.] We were still far enough, far enough. But still we already had a bit of hope. Maybe we will still survive. Maybe we will. And then, as soon as . . . Then came the catastrophe, the forest was attacked.
Who attacked?
The Germans, the Germans. It has been reported thus. This tale was carried to the Gestapo, that thousands of Jews are located in the woods, with ammunition . . .
Hm.
. . . with a secret radio, and with partisans.
Hm.
Imagine what was sent out against us. Whole divisions were sent to surround the woods, and there began a gigantic raid on the forest.
Yes?
They began to search. A raid.
Yes.

The moment the partisans sensed that the woods are being raided, they were recalled. They left us. The radio remained, and they created only a little Jewish partisan group. They organized fifteen young men, Jews. They gave them arms with which to defend themselves. And so we already had a little Jewish partisan group. They left, and the Jewish partisan group got ready to protect us at least against . . . against common bandits who went around robbing. When they had left and we remained in the woods, they were raiding the woods constantly. They had found already the radio.
Hm.
They found the radio. And Jews were being killed. And some bunkers remained. The result was that out of the three hundred and fifty Jews, no more than fifteen remained.
Fifteen?
Fifteen. Then it happened. During the whole summer . . . summer time we were able to hide in the forest, because the leaves were strewn over the bunkers.
Hm.
The moment the snow fell, since we had to go out on the snow occasionally, we left a trail.
Oh!
Footprints.
Yes?
When they attacked the forest in snow time, they saw by the . . . by the footprints. They tracked them down to each . . .
Hm.
. . . bunker. And then began the tragedy in the forest. The few Jews came to be annihilated, the few remaining in the forest.
Hm.
And out of the three hundred and fifty there remained no more than fifteen remained.
Fifteen?
Fifteen.
Hm. Might not some have run away to other places?
No. We were constantly on the run. It was like this. When, for instance, this part of the forest was raided . . . we were in seventeen bunkers . . .
Hm.
Each time we had to run away to another forest. As soon . . . as soon as we were discovered in this little piece of forest . . .
Hm.
. . . we had to leave it and escape to another forest.
And each time you had to build new bunkers.
Build new bunkers. And how these bunkers were built! This is extraordinarily interesting to describe [?].
Hm.
How was one able to build a bunker in the forest? One had to cut down trees.
Hm.
The dug up earth had to be carried away.
Hm.
And it [the structure] had to be propped up underground.
Hm.

And this was made, for instance, in that . . . in that part where we were. If we wanted to build the bunker, trees had to be cut in an entirely other part, because if somebody should come, he shouldn't be able to notice that trees had been cut here. You understand?
Oh! Oh!
You understand?
You needed tree . . . trees for the bunkers.
For the bunkers.
What for did you need trees for bunkers?
Materials, to prop up. If one digs a hole [a cave] it will cave in. It has to be propped up.
Hm.
It has to be propped up.
Hm! Yes.
With material.
Yes?
Nu, and if we should up . . . up . . . uproot the trees here, cut here in the part where we are, if one should come to the forest it will be seen that there are trees missing here.
Yes?
So it will be understood that someone is hidden here.
Yes.
[so] we had to go two, three kilometers, some place else.
Yes.
To another part of the forest, cut the trees there, carry them on the shoulders to this . . . to this part.
Hm.
And later on when the ground was dug up, the earth, too, had to be carried away a few kilometers. It should not be noticed . . .
Yes.
. . . that the earth had been dug up here. That is how bunker was made! And the engineers made a bunker of . . . of . . . of five stories. It is interesting.
Deep?
Deep, underground. And twigs were . . . were kind of braided. And so we slept, one on top of the other, like on plank beds, as it was called.
Yes.
And when the Germans found that bunker!
You mean five levels of beds were made?
Beds, underground.
Yes?
And when that bunker was discovered, they brought down a photographer to photograph it.
Yes?
And they said, 'Look what the Jews can do! A subterranean little Paris.' I heard the voices . . .
Subterranean what?
Subterranean little Paris.
The Germans said that?
The Germans said [that]. When . . . when they discovered the bunker with Jews in it, they took . . . they brought a photographer to photograph it.
Hm.
And they were astonished. They said, 'Look what the Jews can do! A subterranean little Paris!'
Yes. What did they mean by a 'little Paris'?
Because it was so artistically . . .
Hm.
. . . artistically constructed. It was such a masterpiece [Footnote: It is possible that the Germans referred to the famous subterranean structures in Old Paris.].
Yes.

With so . . . with so much . . . with so much effort, with so much . . . .And all that didn't help. The end. The winter brought the catastrophe, and very few were left. We remained fifteen persons only, not in the forest either. If we would have been in the forest these few wouldn't have remained either. We [then] escaped into the villages and persuaded a Gentile [that] he should make a bunker, a hole in a stable.
Hm.
We laid there, four persons, for four months in a stable underneath the cattle.
Who was with you? Your boy?
The boy and two other persons who . . . they had more money to give to that Gentile for my share.
Hm.
The Gentile took exorbitant sums for every day, and I didn't have it. So I led two more people to that Gentile, and they paid for me.
Hm.
We were four persons in a stable where the animals stood on top.
Hm.
And underneath, under the manure, I was lying in a hole for four months.
Nu?
There we lay for four months until the Soviets entered. Before Pesach in the year '44 the Soviets arrived in our parts.
Yes?
So when we heard that the Soviets are here we left the bunkers.
Nu?
And we drove into the town.
What does it mean, 'drove into the town'?
We went [walked] into the town.
Hm.
And then eight days later the Soviets executed a retreat again.
A retreat?
A retreat.
Nu?
They executed a retreat, and we remained. When . . . when we left for the woods, I took a count of those who came back . . .
Oh!
. . . and I had forty-nine people.
From your two hundred and fifty.
Yes, from my three hundred and fifty only fifteen were left, but in other forests, where I didn't know, there were also hidden a few groups.
Nu?
And these came together in my own town. Forty-nine people.
People. Nu?

I took count. I know I had forty-nine people. These were out of a region of hundreds of thousands of people. These few people remained. And when I saw that a retreat is in process, I knew that we are again in mortal danger.
Was this already in the Russian region that you . . .
Yes. We were already . . . .The Russians had already control, had occupied that region, our region.
Aha.
Yes, so I . . . They came out from the woods.
Yes?
I saw that we are forty-nine persons in our little town.
Nu?
I gathered the forty-nine people and thought of starting anew a bit of life.
Yes.
To begin to rebuild [?].
Yes. Nu?
In the meantime, in eight days, I perceived a . . . a tumult.
Hm.
A retreat.
Hm.
I got in touch with a Jewish captain of the Russian army . . .
Hm.
. . . who had . . . I asked what is going on. He said, 'There have broken through . . . we had besieged, surrounded a city with sixteen divisions of German forces . . . '
Yes?
' . . . and our main army went on.'
Hm.
And so as the main army went on, they have broken out and will gain control again of the entire region of Galicia.'
Oh.
'You are again in danger. We are retreating.'
Hm.
So I begged him, 'Take back these forty-nine.' I explained to him that, since out of the many thousands of Jews only forty-nine have remained, I plead with him to take us along with the army.
Yes.

We should be with the army. He granted me this favor and took us along with the army. We ran with the army to the Dniester, twenty-two kilometers, at night. It was something terrible. We couldn't escape [by] ourselves, so we ran with the army.
Didn't they have any carts, automobiles? Any [word not clear]?

There . . . there were, but there was chaos in the retreat. It was said . . . At the beginning he had promised us that he will put the women and children on the vehicles, but when the moment of the retreat came there was such a tumult that we couldn't do it. Each . . . each soldier [?] packed his own . . . his own and ran. And we civilians had to walk. And we ran until the Dniester, and then we crossed over to Horodenka, and we went as far as Czernowitz.
Hm.
As far as Czernowitz. In Czernowitz we saw already . . . At first we thought that we are surrounded, we are caught in Czernowitz. We . . .
By the Germans?
Yes. We thought that we are again surrounded by the Germans. Arriving in Czernowitz, we saw that we are saved, we are in Soviet hands.
Hm.

The Germans are already . . . they won't come here any more. In Czernowitz I . . . I distributed the forty-nine people . . . distributed them there among the Jews. In Czernowitz we found twenty-three thousand Jews . . .
Oh!
. . . who received us very nicely, very well.
The Germans . . . had the Germans ever been in Czernowitz?
They had been.
Nu?
And there they did not do what they have done in Galicia
Hm.
There in Czernowitz had been eighty thousand Jews. They deported sixty, lead them away, but the twenty [thousand] that had remained, remained.
Hm.
Nothing happened to them. I found about twenty-three thousand Jews in Czernowitz, and we got settled, these forty-nine people. And I gained Czernowitz Rabbinat.
Hm.
And I was a year in Czernowitz.
Hm.
Now.
Yes?
In '45 when there started the repa- . . . repatriation to Poland . . .
Yes?
I as a Polish citizen. I had documents made out in Czernowitz and went to Poland.
Hm.
I was in Warsaw for six months as Rabbi of Warsaw.
Hm.
Rabbi of Warsaw.
Hm.
In Warsaw I began organizing a Jewish life. It cost me a lot of effort.
It cost you what?
Effort.
Effort.
Much effort. I saw that I am again in great danger, that danger lurks at every pace and step.
What does it mean, 'danger'?
Danger means . . . in Warsaw a Jew couldn't show up on the street. Should he be recognized that he is a Jew . . .
After the Poles had retaken Warsaw?
After Poland . . .
After the liberation of Poland?
After the liberation of Poland.
What are they . . . why are they . . .
There are pogroms. Don't you know that today there are in Poland . . .
Yes, I know [words not clear].

I will tell you why. It is . . . it is really this way. There has remained the . . . the poison of Hitlerism. There it did more damage than any place else. There Hitlerism took such deep roots that Hitlerism exists there today like an epidemic. It is not possible to notice that anything has changed there, whether Hitlerism has fallen. It is not possible to observe in the Polish regions that anything had happened. It looks like Hitlerism. The . . . the extermination of Jews is still advocated, and they are doing . . . .It is true, the government is still very well disposed. The government wants to control the situation. The government in Poland is very good, but they are unable to control this situation. I saw how in Warsaw with every step I take outside I am in danger. I caught slaps. I was beaten. And I had to walk. Every step I had to walk. I couldn't ride on a streetcar. I had to shave. I shaved off the beard, concealed it with the kerchief. Thus I saw that it is impossible for me to carry out my Jewish life. I began to try, look for ways. I got out of Poland and came to France.
You got out with . . . from Poland with whom?
With a transport with other Jews. Two hundred of the Agudah Israel.
Tell me something about the Agudah Israel. What kind of an organization is that?
Agudah Israel is an organization which endeavors to mold life according to the letter of Torah.
Hm.
That means it endeavors that the whole everyday life, that all that a man has to deal with in life, should proceed in the spirit of the Torah.
Aha.
It endeavors to bring in the Torah spirit into every problem of life.
Aha.
Now Agudah Israel is endeavoring to build the Land of Israel.
Hm.
Because they see that there is no more a place for us in Europe. For those remaining people there is no place.
Were they al- . . . were they always Zionists, the Agudah Israel?

They were once . . . they were for Zion, but not as actively as today. Once they believed that the important thing is to stand guard over the Torah. And it can even be in the Diaspora, but the important thing is to see that the Jewish . . . that the Jewish life be according to the Torah. But today, since they see that in Europe there is no place for a Jew, they endeavor to rebuild the Land of Israel in the spirit of Torah. This is Agudah Israel. Agudah Israel endeavors to create and build a Jewish Home in the Land of Israel, but only in the spirit of the Jewish Torah.
Nu?
This is the Agudah Israel.
And so? How did the Agudah Israel gather the two hundred people, and how did you get in touch with them?

Agudah Israel is like this. When there . . . when it came to be after the catastrophe, after the liberation of Poland, there got together five, six people, no more, who had remained Jewish religious comrades. They went out in the street and they searched, simply searched for children. In Christian homes many [Jewish]children were hidden.
Hm.

And they took each child and clothed it and fed it. And they said, 'You should know you don't have your parents. You have no family. But you are a child of Jews, and you have to be a Jewish child. And you should believe in God.' They began raising these children. Six, seven people had gathered gradually and assembled hundreds of children. They bought them back from Gentiles. A lot of money was paid.
Why did they have to be bought back?

Bought back? Because the Gentile woman didn't want to surrender them. The Gentile woman knew that it was a deal. If she has saved a Jewish child she demands money. People got in touch with the Joint, with the Americans and it was paid, up to thirty thousand for a child, and even up to fifty thousand.
Thirty thousand Zlotys?
Zlotys. And up to fifty thousand Zlotys.
How much was a Zloty worth against the dollar?

Hm. Against the dollar perhaps . . . about thirty thousand Zlotys was about . . . I don't know exactly, but anyway it is quite a sum, hundreds of dollars. One used to give for a child three, four hundred dollars.
And?
That much was given for a child. And these children were bought back, and people began bringing them up in a Jewish was of life. And then a 'Benoss' was created, separately for woman.
What is a 'Benoss'?
'Benoss' means separate quarters for woman.
Yes.
Since they are to lead a life [in the spirit] of the Torah, there should be . . . there cannot be a mixing of men and women.
Hm.
In one Kibbutz there was created a Kibbutz for men separate and a Kibbutz separately for women.
Hm.
And then the older women instructed the younger women. And lectures were always given about the spirit of the Torah.
Hm.
And nowadays there exist in Poland forty-odd Kibbutzim . . .
Hm.
Created by Agudah and . . .
There are other Kibbutzim, too, which were not created by the Agudah?
There are all kinds, Mizrachi Kibbutzim.
Yes.
But I am talking about the Agudah.
Yes, yes.
The program of the Agudah . . . there is of the Mizrachi . . . Mizrachi has other Kibbutzim yet.
Yes.
And then there are just ordinary Zionists, and there are leftist parties. There are all kind of parties.
Yes. All of them have Kibbutzim?
Yes, all have Kibbutzim. All have Kibbutzim. and all . . .
You have to excuse me, but in America . . . I am in another . . .
Yes, yes, yes.
. . . field.
Yes.
And I want to know. You understand?
Of course, of course.
Yes.
I will tell you all I know.
Yes?
All have Kibbutzim, but this I have to bring to your attention. Everybody endeavors to get out of Poland.
Yes.

The leftists even more than the Agudah. All endeavor to get out of Poland, because in this all parties are agreed, that there is no more room for a Jew in Poland. Such doesn't exist! All agree on that.
And?
And we were brought over. I . . . I came with a transport of the Agudah to Prague, to Czechoslovakia. And from Prague . . .
How did you cross the border?
The border we crossed somewhat legally. It was said the border guards had been bribed a little. A whole that . . . It was quite an undertaking.
Yes.
It was successful. That transport left almost legally.
That transport went how? On foot, or in a . . . a . . .
No, no, no.
In busses?
No. We rode . . . we embarked in Warsaw, and we rode as far as Prague. We rode . . .
In what? In [word not clear]?
In . . . in a train.
In a train.
By railroad, by railroad.
Did you buy your tickets or were they free? Or . . .
The tickets were bought till . . . till the . . . till the border, and then we bought tickets again. Our transport was as if a bit legal.
Yes.
Because it was somehow worked through with . . . with an understanding with the authorities . . .
Yes.

. . . who gave a permit. And there were some kind of passports. It was illegal and legal, but in any case somewhat legally. And we arrived in good order. However the transports that are leaving now walk already about twenty-odd kilometers.
Hm.
Troubles are already happening at the borders.
Hm.

They are arriving naked and barefoot. And still thousands of Jews are leaving Poland. People are breaking out by any means in their power, because there had been already burned offerings, because there are pogroms in Poland.
Hm.
Arriving in France, as you know, we arrived in Hénonville, and here . . .
How did you cross? For Prague you went where to?
To Paris, to Paris.
How did you travel, by train or how?
By train, by train, by train from Prague to Paris.
And who provided the food? Who provided the . . .
And who provided all the things? There is an Agudah in Prague.
Hm.
And there is an Agudah in France.
Yes.
And there is the Vaad Hatzala [words not clear -- interrupted].
The what?
The Vaad Hatzala from America.
Hm.
In America there exists such a rescue movement . . .
Yes.
. . . rescue movement, Vaad Hatzala.
Vaad Hatzala?
Vaad Hatzala.
Vaad Hatzala.
Vaad Hatzala. That means Committee for Rescue.
Yes.
Rescue committee. The Vaad Hatzala is now spread over the whole . . . the whole of Europe. And they rescue the Shaarith Haplatim. Their mission is to rescue the Shaarith Haplatim.
What does it mean, Shaarith Haplatim? The survivors?
[Words not clear] don't help the killed, the survivors.
But what do the two words mean?
Shaaro [?] is survived. Haplatim, who had escaped.
Escaped . . .
Escaped.
The survivors of those who had escaped.
Of . . . yes. The survivors of those who escaped . . .
Yes.
. . . who had succeeded in saving their lives . . .
Yes.
. . . in the forests. Shaarith Haplatim means that.
Yes.
And the Vaad Hatzala, it has the mission to rescue the Shaarith Haplatim, and to take them out from the dangerous countries . . .
Hm.
. . . and bring them, for the time being, into such a country where a Jew can more or less move freely. He is still na vanat [roaming and wandering], but he is able to move freely.
He is still what?
Na vanat [roaming and wandering]. He is not in his own home.
Yes.

He has no place. He has no place to sleep. He is still in . . . in bad circumstances as to food and . . . and so forth. For instance, we here are . . . We live under hard conditions. Here, indeed, in Hénonville
Yes.

But still we are in a country where we can move about freely. The Jew is a man equal to all men in France. I can go out in France as a Jew with a beard. As a religious Jew. And I can ride on all those . . . on . . . on the Metros, on the Busses, the same as all . . . as all . . . as all people. This we have. In this [respect] we are saved. And furthermore, you should know that all the Jews have an aim, to go to Israel. All of them from Agudah Israel and from other parties have the aim, simply to have as their own a little piece of home, a little piece of country [?]. Some people who have relatives in America are struggling to get to America, because, for the time being, the road to the Land of Israel is complicated. But the majority consists of [us] idealists who, in spite of the situation there being difficult, we want solely to come to Eretz Israel. And this, the hope of the . . . this is . . . of the . . . of the . . . this is the . . . the expectation of all the Kibbutzim, that people are waiting, that any moment they will be able to tear themselves through into Eretz Israel, whether legally or illegally. To us Eretz Israel is always legal. Our journey to Eretz Israel is legal because it is our country, and we are going there as to our own. This is our hope.
Rabbi Horowitz, would you please tell me something, a little about Hénonville. How many people are here? What does one do here, and how did they come, and . . . and so forth?
Here . . . here in Hénonville we are a kind of Hachshara.
Hm, here is a Hachshara?
Hachshara. What does Hachshara mean? It means that it is a preparation for Eretz Israel. We want to come to Eretz Israel as active people.
What does the word Hachshara mean?
Hachshara means . . . means . . . means preparation.
Preparation.
Preparation.
Hm.

We want to prepare ourselves, build our bodily conditions, so that we should be able to act- . . . actively to build the land, not come there as people who have to be assured an existence, but capable of building and creating. Here in Hénonville exists a Kibbutz. People work at gardening. People work on the field. People work at carpentry. People work at tailoring.
Hm.

People work as painters, at shoe making. And all these . . . everyone learns according to his trade, for which he is capable, [so] he should come to Eretz Israel as a tradesman, so he should be able with his trade to help in building the land. We should be able by ourselves to conduct all the branches of life.
Hm.
We shouldn't need any protectorate over us.
And how is this . . . how . . . how many people are there here in Hénonville?
Now there are arriving more. Here there were already over two hundred. Now there could be assembled about three hundred.
Hm.
There will be installed a seminary, too.
A . . . a Yeshiva?
A Yeshiva, yes. I as a spiritual leader . . .
Hm.
I, Horowitz, as the spiritual leader see to it that all these labors should be carried out in the spirit of the Torah.
Hm.
That means, for instance, in the morning when we get up . . .
Hm.
Everything is punctual. At six o'clock there is a bell. It rings. Everybody has to stand on the square. Up and about.
Hm.

The people are taught punctuality. He should know punctually. He should do everything punctually. Until eight o'clock there is a prayer and breakfast. Prayer first. After breakfast I give a lecture studying the Torah. I give a lecture to the men. They are taught for an hour or two. Then people go to work.
Hm.
People go to work until dinner.
And at what time do people go to work?
People go to work at nine. At nine everybody has to be at work.
Hm.
People work eight hours a day.
Hm.
Eight . . . eight hours one works. At nine people go to work . . . twelve . . . until twelve or half past. The bell rings. People know it is dinner. Everybody leaves the work and goes to eat dinner.
Hm.
After dinner, at two . . . two o'clock the bell rings again. People know and go to work again, and until six people work.
Hm.
At six people come home.
[In English] This concludes Spool number 120. [End of Spool 120.]
[In English] This is Spool 121. I continue with the Rabbi Solomon Horowitz.
[In Yiddish] And so, Rabbi, would you tell me . . . you have described to me a little of Hénonville. Now I should like to ask you a question.
Yes. I . . . I want to add [word not clear] . . .
Yes, go ahead. Say anything you want. The microphone is yours.

Yes. I want to add something about the life, how here, really, people strive that there be a brotherly life. One for another would walk into fire. The love of one for another becomes here forged together. All of us are constantly together. One treasury, one food, one treatment. When one gets married here, it is a joyful event for everyone. Everyone joins in the happiness. A joy the same as if his own brother would . . . would get married. And his life creates in the people a great love of one for another. This is almost the . . . the most important asset of the life in a kibbutz.
Hm.

That it creates a bond of one another. Everyone is taken by love of one for another, with loyalty because one . . . one loses the individual [personal] problems, the individual endeavors, and everything ties into one collective endeavor. We all have one aim and one endeavor.
Eh . . . I would like to ask you . . .
Yes.
. . . a question.
Yes.
The old Jewish life . . .
Yes.
. . . was that planned as a collective life and not as a family life and an individual life?
Yes.
I would like to know how . . . how do you understand the . . .
In the Torah?
In the Torah, yes.
[In] our Torah, as you know, there is a main tenet: 'L'haftu le rayachu komochu.'
What does it mean?
That means to love your . . . your comrade the same as yourself.
Where is that in the Torah? Where is it written?
The Torah is to us . . . us . . .
No, I mean what you just said, that . . . that . . .
'L'haftu le rayachu komochu.'
Yes.
That was said by God, and Moses wrote it down.
Can you give me the verse? Where is it?
Yes!
Where is it?
'L'haftu l'rayachu w'komoch. Annee Adoshem' [Love thy neighbor as thyself. I am God].
Yes?
That must be in Ki Tetzay [see Note 3 at end of chapter].
I would like to know it, you understand. The . . . the Christians are always claiming that this is their . . . [i.e., was first proclaimed by the New Testament -- see same Note 3] . . .
They took it from us.
Yes?
They took it from Torah. This is written clearly in the Torah. When I look it up I shall tell you the exact place.
Yes.
But this . . . I shall look it up and . . .
Yes.
[Words not clear.]
Yes.
I will tell you the exact place.
Hm.
The verse and everything. [See same Note 3 at end of chapter.]
Hm.
But that it is in the Torah, that is for sure. Sure.
Yes.
I can soon tell you . . .
Yes.
. . . the location of the place.
Nu?
[Words not clear.] If not more . . . [chuckle] the important thing is to carry it out exactly.
Yes.

All right. This is the main concept. The main concept of our Torah is that one man should love another and in dealing with another not to deceive another, live a decent life, and in every . . . everyone . . .
One moment. [Testing the microphone.] Live a decent life, you said. Nu, go on.
And . . . [pause] . . .
Yes?
And . . . and endeavor to do such things that should bring usefulness to the whole community, not only to oneself.
Hm. Nu, I want to ask you another question.
Yes.
I understand that there are here . . .
Yes.
. . . Russian women . . . eh . . . who became Jews.
Who became converted?
Yes.
Where? Here in the Kibbutz?
No, no, no. I was told that there are here, here in Hénonville. Women who were Christians before [Footnote: For some information on this topic see interview with Mrs. Clara Neuman, Spool 121B.].
Hm. Geirim, geirim, geirim [strangers].
Would you tell me something about them?
I don't know the story. Why they became converted I don't know. I know only that they are extremely religious Jews. That only, I know.
Yes. You don't know their story, how they have come? What . . .
No. I met them in the group . . .
Yes?
. . . leaving Poland for here.
Yes?
I met them in the group, and seeing that the Torah says thirty-six times, 'L'haftu mes'hagayra' [Love the stranger within the gates] . . .
What does it mean?
In the Torah it says thirty-six times to love a stranger, to give assistance to a stranger . . .
Yes.
. . . who comes over to our religion. He has to be treated even better because he feels so . . . so lonesome, so . . . so not . . . not . . . not wanted.
Yes.
It is self-understood that we are very friendly towards these strangers [Geirim].
Hm.
And we . . . we give them very much attention. And they are feeling very well, and they are highly religious.
Hm.
They take part in all the Jewish things. They study.
Hm.
And they are highly religious. And I only know that . . . that they are very satisfied. But their history, how they came to it, that I don't know.
Hm.
It is unknown to me.
Hm. Nu, when do you think this Kibbutz will leave for Eretz Israel?
There has left already a transport from . . . from . . . from Hénonville for Eretz Israel about two months ago. A hundred and forty people . . .
Illegally?
Illegally . . .
Yes?
. . . who are writing very good letters . . .
Hm.
. . . and are happily in Eretz Israel . . .
Hm.
. . . in spite of the situation still being so . . . so . . . We are hoping any day . . . But Hénonville a transit [place] for thousands of more Jews.
Hm.
France is an important point now.
Hm.

Thousands of Jews are still endeavoring to come here. And Hénonville is a point that when these two hundred Jews leave, a place is made for a new two hundred Jews. As long as the repatriation will last in . . . in Europe, so long, I think, Hénonville will exist, until there will be created a real Jewish Home and life will become normal. Hénonville is a point that is not for a day or two.
Hm.

It is transit point. And every Saturday strangers come to us. Even those who are not from Hénonville, who are living in Paris. They come here for every Saturday, thirty, forty guests, to take part in our Sabbath . . . [See interview with Mr. Pinkhus Rosenfeld in forthcoming volumes, Spools 130B and 131.]
Hm.
. . . which is most interesting. We spend a Sabbath from beginning to end full of Godliness, with diffidence, with lectures, with study. The whole Sabbath is to us a spiritual day, free of labor.
Hm.

Here there are such religious people. Saturday no work is done, but the whole day, Saturday, is spent in songs with . . . with dances. People are dancing together. [he refers to ritual dances of the Khassidic sect].
Hm.

We sing together, and we eat together, and lectures about the Torah are given. And every week according to the Sedra[ a weekly portion of the Pentateuch] . . . the spirit of the Sedra is explained, the devine meanings. And all these thing and the good customs are taught. I teach Perak every Saturday. I teach Perak. Perak, that means about the customs.
Yes.

How a man should be. He should . . . should . . . should find for himself the customs. And that is how Sabbath is spent. For every Sabbath there are thirty, forty guests here who come simply to see how Jews are living together spiritually.
What kind of guests are they, also from Kibbutzim or . . . ?

No, no, no, not from Kibbutzim. Just from Paris. People who . . . who are going . . . are waiting for visas to go to America, to Chicago, to Canada. But they have heard about Heno so they come out here for the Sabbath. And we, from our food, we share with [them] no matter who, as many guests as there come. We eat collectively together. And Sunday they take leave and depart.
Hm.
They simply come to partake [?] and see how a day is spent here.
Hm.
We have organized all the things pertaining to Jewishness. For instance, now I am planning to make a Mikvah [ritual bath].
Hm.
That is needed for a family cleanliness, family life. It plays a great role in the Torah. It is one of the most important commands of the Torah: To lead a clean family . . . family life.
Hm.

And we are hoping to build now a Mikvah. The Sabbath is very much observed here with all the finest details. And here is being led, as one says, a socially constructive life, and a religious, Godly life. That is how it is led here in the Kibbutz.
Tell me, will you allow me to use the machine on Saturday?
Saturday? Here? [In an apologetic whisper apparently to avoid the recording of his words] No. Not here.
I am not writing . . .
[Whisper] But it is an apparatus . . .
[Chuckle. Words not clear.]
. . . an apparatus. It is not [word not clear].
Nu?
What for? You want to come out for Saturday? You are very welcome.
I want to stay here for . . . I am leaving already for America on Tuesday.
But I still want to talk with many people here.
Will you stay over Saturday?
Well, I can't remain over . . . I want to stay here Friday and maybe Saturday till . . . but only if I could use the machine.
No, no.
No.
Saturday it is not allowed. But you could on Saturday night. You could . . . we sit at . . . we have organized now. Saturday night is the termination of Sabbath.
Yes.
It is also spent in a Sabbath manner.
Yes.
Sabbath night is spent by Khassidim . . . 'Melava malka' [the exit of the queen] it is called by us. Saturday night you could record as it . . . Saturday, more or less.
Yes.
But on Saturday proper, it is Sabbath with us.
Yes.
It is not permitted [words not clear].
And so, as you say.
But on Saturday proper . . .
Nu? Is there anything more that you might want to say to the American Jews?

To the American Jews. In the first place I am sending over my great gratitude for their initiative, for their help to all our brothers of the Shaarith Haplatim. To tell the truth, if not helped by America the Shaarith Haplatim would not be able to exist, and the surviving Jews would have simply fallen apart. Thanks to their initiative, their help in every sphere, that really strengthened the broken up, surviving Jews of the Shaarith Haplatim, and this gives them the possibility of existing anew and to begin living anew. But I want to tell our American brothers, they should know that the aid that they are giving is really very big. The aid is very important. But an adjustment we have not achieved yet. We wander from one country to another, whether we . . . we are sitting here in Kibbutz, or others in other places. But we lead a na vanat [roaming and wandering] life.
What does it mean?

A hard life, and we don't see the morning before us yet. We don't see the salvation before us yet. The aim of all of us is Eretz Israel. And at present Eretz Israel is still so complicated. The entry to Eretz Israel is still to complicated with various frustration, with various obstacles. They should know, the American Jews, that indeed they are the only brothers who can save us, who can help us. And they should remember always to be in contact with all the Jews that find themselves in Europe, and to send messengers to every point to become acquainted with the conditions and with what they have to be helped. And to help with something really important, that means, to lead [us] out from Galuth [Diaspora] and to bring [us] into a little safe harbor.

[In English] This concludes the interview from Spool number 119, transferred . . . continued on Spool number 120 [Footnote: The spool numbers are given incorrectly. The interviewer was apparently distracted or overcome by the content of the interview. The correct numbers are 120, and 121, or to be exact 120 and 121A since the second part of Spool 121 contains a different interview.] with Rabbi Solomon Horowitz, the spiritual leader of a Jewish group of displaced people at Hénonville next . . . near to Paris. Illinois Institute of Technology wire recording. September 12, 1946. France.
div.p: Note 3 for page - 47 - (2033): The section [Sedra] Ki Tetzay covers a portion of Deuteronomy beginning with verse 10, chapter 21, and concluding with the last verse of chapter 25. Although this section extensively preaches the most humane treatment of stranges 'within thy gates,' it does not contain the quotation to which the interviewee refers. This quotation is not to be found in the section [Sedra] Kedoshim, and twice in the same chapter 19 of Liviticus: once, verse 18, in the exact wording of the interviewee, and again in a slightly different wording, but with direct reference to 'the stranger that sojourneth with you,' in verse 34. In the New Testament the proper quotation in the exact wording of the interviewee will be found in Mathew 22:39. These references may, of course, be found by checking with any Concordance, however, the writer feels that he is in good company when he confesses that up to this interview he had but little motivation to clear up this matter for himself, and that the query arose in the interview as a consequence of Rabbi Horowitz's statement. —D.P.B.

Note 4 for page - 9 - (1995): One cannot help feeling that some factual items in this interview are lacking precision, or may represent in certain particulars bias-colored hearsay. A victim of a catastrophe may not always be its best historian, but his reports, like items of folklore, give a definite portrayal of moods, and may render valuable leads for historical, anthropological, and psychological follow-ups. —D.B.P.
